newsitem.title: GERMANY: Germany to collect 20 bln marks from smokers in 96.
newsitem.headline: Germany to collect 20 bln marks from smokers in 96.

text.p: German Finance Minister Theo Waigel, under the gun to find money to plug holes in the budget, can count on collecting a good 20 billion marks ($13.28 billion) from smokers this year, a study said on Sunday.
The Ifo economic institute said smokers in Germany would inhale 35.6 billion marks worth of cigarettes during the year.
But cheaper cigarettes in neighbouring countries, along with smuggled ones, will cost Bonn about 1.9 billion marks in lost tax revenues.

Despite the hefty intake of funds from smokers, Ifo said the tax funds were not a way for Waigel to raise revenues to help whip Germany's finances into shape for European currency union, which is set to start in January 1999.
The report said German smokers would have "a strong allergic reaction" to any attempt to raise cigarette taxes, saying smokers would cut back on the habit if that happened.
The report said a higher cigarette tax would on average prompt each smoker to cut back by a minimum of 350 cigarettes a year.
The Ifo report also predicted the German cigarette market through the year 2000 should remain steady.
Sales in 1996 should reach 135.7 billion cigarettes but grow to only 136.7 billion cigarettes in 2000, meaning tax revenues would be steady in current dollars through 2000. ($1=1.5063 Mark)
